number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												I have spent many hours with this game on both PC and Ipad. I prefer playing this on ipad, and i see there has been a major update for PC. Is there going to be a similar update for ios? Soon?? I do also have some suggestions and critisisms for this game. The AI/pathing needs some serious attention. Giving more control over the dwarves. I find it frustratingly difficult to get them to do what i want. I get the concept of not having direct control or having to micro manage the dwarves, but I want more control. Don't let this concept get in the way of developing a great game that people want to keep playing. I want to be  a god not an annoying arrow pointer that tries to direct the path. If you need more money to develop, I would not be opposed to buying cheap dlc for new worlds with quircky little themed challenges. Bring em on (ipad)! Or even a world editor/creator.The market could also use some updating. maybe trading with other worlds that we have created. I spend too much time mining gold coins to buy health potions so i can survive each wave. I like the challenge of the waves and i like the countdown timer so i can prepare.I also find the traps and farming aspects of the game specifically ineffective, boring and useless. Herding sheep for wool, however is useful, but too time consuming. We should also be able to herd other beasts for meat and hides relatively easier. Traps are useless and non existent in my strategies to defend against the waves. Once i finally get the dwarves to place the trap it is destroyed before it even does anything and i have to wait and hopefully survive the wave before i can regather the trap then place them all again...it was a frustrating and useless strategy...please fix that. I like the concept of the tesla thing but it needs to be more powerfull, and maybe an ice or fire cannon or something. Amp up the tower defence aspect of the game a little.I am not by any means trying to discourage people from getting this game. You should definately get it. Support the developers, because they are on to something with this game. It takes almost all of my favorite game genres and puts them all into one promising game! Overall this game is great, but it could be awesome if the developers keep going with it...on ipad especially!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Been playing this game nonstop since I got it. Very VERY polished and playable game especially for Steam's notorious Early Access program. This game has more content and is more stable than many indie full releases here on Steam.A mix of Terraria's 2D world with Dwarf Fortress' dwarves and industries along with a dose of Minecraft-style box crafting interface. This sounds awful, but first it's not eye-destroying because the entire game has a hand-drawn art style and not the overdone pixel-y aststyle of games like it. Resources seem to be plentiful but there is definite challenge in the waves of enemies that spawn above ground and you find underground. Defnitely a fun base building game thats easy to get a grasp on and also is easy to make awesome looking bases in. I love it so far, it has a massive tech tree to work through BUT one aspect of the otherwise great UI bugs me to no end. This game has an absolutely enormous amount of objects to put in the hotbar and all of them are only accessible through another menu that is tabbed. So it can take forever to exchange the items you need into the hotbar. Hopefully that issue is fixed before the game leaves Early Access.Otherwise, STRIKE THE EARTH (and spiders, goblins, zombies, etc)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								My ten-hours-in review: it was rough figuring out how things worked initially.  It doesn't explain some important things (like how to build "shelter") but if you dig a little online, it's easy to get sorted out, and I believe that the menus will probably be improved.  That being said, once I got the game sorted out after a couple hours of fiddling, I started really enjoying myself.  It's a pretty forgiving game so far, and I've taken quite a shine to my little tribe of dwarves.  I can relax and enjoy the exploration without feeling like one of my guys will get stupid and fall in a lake of fire.  The waves of monsters from time to time have been something of a challenge, but I have yet to see what happens if you get wiped out.  Individual dwarves respawn after a delay when killed.  All in all, it's an enjoyable little time waster, and you like build and explore games, there's a lot to like here.  I heartily recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Imagine, if you will, a world run by dwarfs who need to craft this world to survive hordes of monsters spawned by portals that appear every 50 minutes and find the 5 underground rooms guarded by a keeper so they can access the portal to another world. -the good-Fun and addictive (18 hours of obsessive crafting, digging, and fighting per world)Graphically impressive (it's pretty)4 different worlds (especially the 4th one)Unique (never seen a game quite like this before)-the bad-Not much in tutorial (not evident you could assign quick bar)Bosses are all the same (same dude 5x on 4 different world)Drags out a bit (2 hours of where is that last boss)Uninspired name (craft the world... Come on!!!)-the ugly-Click drag, click drag, click drag, click drag, click drag, click drag, click drag, click drag, click drag, and finally... CRAFT. (You only have to do this one, on each world, to 'open' the formula, but it's a pain and if you mistakenly double click, you are starting all over. Once you open the formula, just click on the craft button twice to make more.)-the bottom line-I had to limit myself to a lengthy break from this game after finishing each world, because it was the focus of my life for that 20 hours. Very addicting and fun. There is always something to do, and your crafted homes and be quite remarkable. Get this game if you like crafting and/or strategy.-spoilers/strategy-...............Get the scaffolding ASAP (it's reusable and doesn't have to be placed by a dwarf)Get the tesla ASAP (it's stackable, up to three, and will kill intruders easily if you have enough)The elevator goes down 28 levels and no more (plan accordingly, you'll need multiple)Control a dwarf to instantaneous place what ever you need. (Very useful for making bridges)Keep cutting wood (you can craft coal from it later)Buy the warrior, archer, and Mage books (if you haven't found any) and train your dwarfs early.You will likely have 12 dwarfs (I found 6 warriors, 3 archers, 3 Mages a good combo)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
In short, I do recommend to buy it, and highly recommend for "management genre" enthusiast.Personal opinion below --Art style: The charming cartoonish 2D design.Sound & Music: Average, and it gets old really quick after a few repeats.Gameplay: This is the big dilemma...On one side, the fundamental gameplay just keeps on giving. The core design of this game really shines for the management genre.Then there are three "turn-offs" on the opposite side:1. Bugs, pre-and-post patches.2. Gameplay does not scale well with play time.3. Lack of attachment.Replayability: Believe it or not, this is where both the blessing and the curse begins...The replay value is really high, extremely so.But every time when I start a new game, I fear I will feel the same emptiness upon reaching certain play time.Then I tell myself, that, I will just start a new game upon feeling the same emptiness...

Posted: August 2, 2015
												the game really is a good one, BUT some of the current parameters of the maps are not logical. trees almost do not grow at all on the snow map, so wood is a severely short commodity. ive cleared the snow away trying to make the trees grow on the ground, but it doesnt seem to work well. unfortunately, it is a staple for the tech tree, food for the dwarves, and shelter. water is also a problem. you should be able to melt snow at the campfire and make water, or melt it anywhere to make water. the only current way is to build an underground stone pool and stack snow on a bridge above it to melt on its own. even this is problematic. apparently snow cant be stacked more than 1 tile high while underground. dwarves cant walk on the log bridge without falling and getting hurt. ladders are worth their weight in gold because of the wood shortage. i have none to spare.the wandering yetis are a nightmare. they frequently wander into your house, knocking down walls and preventing dwarves from working or healing between night attacks and monster waves. ive got one that patrols the little stretch of hallway in front of my stockpile. all my dwarves are nearly dead, so no one will fight it. game progression is at a standstill until he wanders away.checking the community forums reveals these problems have been around for a long time. the devs need to address them and release a hotfix.

content:

Early Access Review
								I like games like Keflings, Terraria, and Minecraft. I picked it up because it looked right up my alley. I gave it a try and suddenly it was 8 hours later... Its very much one of those "just one more thing" games. I really enjoy having the dwarves do my dirty work and just managing everything rather than doing it all myself like in other games. The AI seems pretty good. There are a lot of things to make, and you're left to build whatever you want with them. I liked the variety of enemies, and the occasional waves of attacks to keep you focused. There's really a lot in the game as it stands now.In starting you are kind of left to your own devices to figure things out. The tech tree is pretty clear and there is a help section in the book with the basics, but the main thing I just totally didn't get on my own until at least a couple hours in was how to build a house- ie a secure shelter. My dwarves were getting beat up and wouldn't eat or sleep. I thought you had to build the wood walls etc that you don't unlock till later, so I was frantically trying to get that far in the tree, and even then I had no idea how to actually make walls on top of the background. My friend had to eventually show me.Seeing as this game isn't even done yet, I can't wait to see what more they add!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Before I get into it, let me just say that this title is actually fairly fun. It seems like a good time killer and feels like something really appropriate for your smartphone while you're on a train or taking a break at work. That is also why I am giving this a thumbs down. This IS a smart phone game lazily ported to PC. It still FEELS like a mobile game despite being on a much more powerful machine. Gameplay-wise, there is some clumsiness in design that goes beyond the "its a mobile game on pc" thing. You upgrade skills and unlock new abilities, but the order in which you unlock them seems to be almost random. You need to build through a few tech trees before you can make basic building components like doors. These are the things you need at the very beginning of the game and by the time you can make them, you've already worked around not having them... thus you don't need them. Also some components like wool to make rope are exceedingly hard to come by and you won't see a sheep until you're further along... thus having recipes at the very start which require rope really sucks. This game doesn't deserve the bad rap I'm giving it. Make no mistake it EARNS a thumbs down, but it really doesn't deserve it. These are things that the developer should have put a little more time and effort into to make a polished game. The graphics are otherwise great. The gameplay is very nonchalant and casual. And over all the game is very relaxing to play. These are great traits that could have made this an amazing game... but in a few key areas it just seems to fall short. Make no mistake, you're buying a mobile game for PC here and it has enough design flaws that you'll lose your love for this game the longer you play. And I say this because this game is definitely a game that should be loved. I feel like maybe another 3-6 months of development could have made a massive difference in this game. Who knows. Sans a major content patch fixing things.. i'd say pass on craft the world unless you see it on a deep sale.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												This sort of game never really appealled to me before; however, it a gem of a game that I have thoroughy enjoyed for a very long playtime. Initially there is a steep learning curve for getting started, but the charming and progressive gameplay really draws you in. The premise of the game is simple, build a home for your dwarfs and get them to delve deep into the earth to discover rare materials needed to strengthen the dwarfs home and their own gear. Each world requires you to survive and then  find the portal on to the next world. This can take 10-15 hours of playtime per level and the final world is very challenging, with enough variety to keep the tech tree engaging.  For the price, this game is a bargain, especially if I compare the played time I have on lots of other expensive games that cost far far more. Hopefully the developers will continue to add new worlds and techs to this very charming and addictive game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												If you enjoyed Terraria then Craft the World is the next best thing. The game features a campaign mode with 4 maps which increase in size and difficulty. The objective is to gather materials to create a shelter and equipment to allow your dwarfs to meet increasingly difficult waves of enemies who attack at night. You create everything from armour, weapons, furniture, food and potions with the ultimate goal of opening a portal to the next level. The game worlds are not as large as Terraria and the limited metals make it impossible to fully equip your dwarves in the best armour and equipment except on the larger maps. Unlike Terraria you don’t directly control a single character but instead issue commands which the dwarves then carry out, this allows you to queue large construction projects or mine huge areas and simply sit back and watch the dwarves complete the tasks. You can construct various defences which allow you to automate your defence, I found this part of the game the most enjoyable as your hard mining and crafting is eventually awarded with a base your enemies can’t breech. On the negative side the game suffers from strange path finding issues, sometimes dwarves stand motionless with an icon above their head indicating that they can’t find a way to get to a location. It’s understandable when the location is miles away but as you mine and create complex tunnel systems they become more frequently lost even when going a short distance. It’s also a shame that nothing carries over to the next level. You open a portal to the next map but you start that map with nothing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Alright, I've just finished Craft the World and I figured I'd give my two cents worth. So the game, as advertised, was a mostly fun mix of Dungeon Keeper and Terraria. With dwarves. I enjoyed the first half of the game (about 33 hours for me) immensely but after that I realized the rest was more of the same. There just isn't enough variety between levels. That's not to say I didn't enjoy the second half. I did. Quite a bit in fact. But it definitely started to drag on, especially in the last level.The two biggest complaints I have with this game are the mana regeneration and the dwarf AI. With the way the game works you *need* mana for portals and it doesn't regenerate nearly fast enough. Running out of mana can make already tedious tasks such as gathering deep down minerals take hours instead of minutes.Then there's the dwarfs. Dear God the dwarfs. I hate to be overly critical but these little guys have some of the worst AI programming I've ever encountered in a game of this type. They get lost constantly, stand dying in front of enemies when they've been ordered to go home, idly stare at blocks they *should* be mining because the game assigned the job to a dwarf all the way across the map, etc. They are just plain stupid and make the game far more frustrating than it should be.It may seem that I'm complaining a lot when you consider that I *do* recommend the game. The fact is, despite it's flaws, it's still a lot of fun and the developer seems to be steadily updating it and listens to the community feedback. If you're hungry for a Dungeon Keeper-esque game or can't get enough of the survival/gathering/crafting type game, I would recommend giving it a try. But, oh, not at full price. No. I'd suggest waiting until it's $10 or under. As it stands, I don't feel it's worth $18.99.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I'm going to review this game with the premise that it one of a few games that could be categorized as Dwarf Fortress like, and will refer to DF throughout the review. The game has some major flaws, but overall it's a great game and is well worth the price. I'll start with the negatives. The AI is not great. The dwarves have a strange way of prioritizing what needs done, so you can't queue up too many task at once, or it will take forever for the important ones to get finished. They also path terribly sometimes, ignoring nearby warp portals if was built after they decided to go somewhere. They will also walk into a hole another dwarf is about to fill to pick up dirt, and will just stand there deciding what to do next, rather than realize they will be trapped. Also wood is far too important for building for not being able to reliable plant it yourself. You end up using the portal spell to send your dwarves out onto the fringe of the world for a few trees all the time. The tech tree is also very poorly implemented. The order in which the dwarves research things is very strange, with seemingly easy things towards the end of the tree and hard things at the beginning. It also forces you to make countless items you'll never use, simply to advance the tree. Combat can also seem kinda clunky, as dwarves will sometimes waltz away from a monster wave simply because none of the monsters are marked for combat. The lack of a profession system is also very irritating. In DF and many DF like games, you assign your dwarves/gnomes/goblins/etc a job, and they perform that job. Such as smith, miner, logger, etc. In this game all dwarves do everything. There is a skill system (dwarves gain up to 3 skills in things such as logging, swimming, archery, etc), and I've read that a job is done by the dwarf with the highest skill in that task, who is currently not doing anything. While I'm not sure if this system even works, it is a bad idea to begin with. The game can also begin to be repetitive. At 21.6 hours I've beat the first world and have moved onto the second world. You simply begin back at square one, with one dwarf and an empty tech tree. The only difference is that the world is harder. I can easily see how other people with more hours and who have gotten to further worlds say that by world 5 the game is boring. Now to the good. The side view 2D is an interesting perspective, and fresh from many of the other top down view DF like games, or any city builders in general. The fortress defense mechanic is very fun. Although the nightly skeleton/zombie hordes do not get any more challenging, the hourly monster raids do start to get harder. This is until all your dwarves are equipped with mithril weapons/armor, at which point the game becomes fairly easy again. The tech tree, while overall being badly implemented, can do a good job at driving you forward to research new items. There are several types of metal to work with, which leads to a nice flow of upgrading your weapons. There are also several types of walls/roofs (once you finally research them), so you can make cool looking forts. Although the game does discourage making individual bedrooms (by keeping interior doors until well into the tech tree) and this does detract from making interesting looking forts. Once you also get farming (well into the tech tree, this is another negative) you can make interesting looking fortresses with attached underground farms. This is always one of my most fun parts of DF like games. The spells are nice too, and make you feel much more involved than many DF like games. Dwarves getting tired of eating certain food too often, forcing you to take advantage of the different types of food available. While I love Gnomoria, I hate knowing I can just grow wheat and my gnomes will never get tired of eating wheat bread and drinking wheat beer (in fact spamming wheat in it is to your advantage). Overall, the thrill of the first 15-30 hours is great. You want to explore just one more tunnel before you go to sleep, and the portal spell makes exploring the fringes of the world much more accessible. If you don't mind spending 20 dollars on a great 30 hours, and then (from what I've heard) an "eh" another 20 hours before the game is just too repetitive, then this is a great game for you. If you are a fan of a DF and are looking for something less intense and requires less time and energy, this game is also great for you (or if you are too scared to jump straight into DF but want to play a fortress builder).

Early Access Review
								All in all, this is a very very good game considering it is still curently only in early access! I havent yet encountered any bugs to my surprise and this game certainly has a lot of potential to be expanded upon, not that there isnt already plenty there for the time being!The only VERY minor problem I have with this game is the difficulty, in that as you progress through the game, it doesn't seem to get much harder as you develop, to the point where even on a game with the difficulty set to nightmare, I am having very little trouble with monsters including the large waves that appear every so often once you reach roughly about the 2 hour mark. The other thing I feel that woild make a good improvement would be the ability to switch at somepoint from a standard game to a permant death game, and then be unable to reverse, as following my above comment, it is quite easy to have a dwarf die in the early stages of the game, but once you reach the stage where you have a base up and running with multiple dwarves, the game does become easier, and I think this may reintroduce some of the challange back into the game at a later stage.However as I said these are very minor points, and all in all a very fun game that has plenty of content and is really promising. I highly recommend this game!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								Craft The World is a lot 'deeper' than I thought, pun intended. I have been playing this a lot over the last few days, and it has been very enjoyable and pulls me back. The crafting tree is huge, so I haven't made it through to the end yet. My play style is more of the build and explore type, so I have not rushed to the end yet. In fact, due to loading onto my laptop and desktop both, I've been playing two different campaigns, and enjoying both. I hope that the alternate world/terrain types open up more replayability. But I still have lots of playability left to go.The closest comparison that comes to mind is Gnomoria, though graphically, it is like comparing the original DOS XCOM to the latest 3D versions.It is an 'early access' game, so I am not certain what changes might be in store. Obviously, new content is still being added, such as the new Snow world and the Yeti boss. At this stage, I do wish that it was possible to actually 'lose', but it appears that it is impossible to be wiped out entirely. There are some bugs that get revealed in edge-case scenarios, and this may be why, on one occasion, my last dwarf did not die. He kind of bugged at zero health, and I was able to recover him and un-bug him, and the game continued as new dwarfs joined him to rebuild.It's artwork is lush and beautiful, the sound effects are very good, the enemies are tough in the beginning, though once you get better equipment, the surface enemies are 'easy'. However, there are more enemies waiting for the dwarves in the depths. I can hear their drums calling to me now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The game is fine. It's not something I've really regretted buying. I just wish that the game had a bit more variety to it. Every level is a case of doing exactly the same thing as you did on the previous level. While the incidental difficulty of the maps becomes greater (i.e. monsters are more difficult), I found it easier to mine necessary resources at later levels. I only just had enough mithril on my first map to finish the game, and with just enough to make a single mithril helmet and sword - not enough for 12 dwarves. If it weren't for the christmas easter egg equipment, I probably wouldn't have been able to survive the portal guardians.The game is also super slow. Like Civ 3 slow. It took me about 18 hours to finish the first level. Much of the wait is held up in watching dwarves haul materials across the screen. While this *is* sped up by various spells and techs, the technology tends to be fairly expensive to produce (on level 1, I was using most of my resources to build a rail system to haul resources back to make railway carts and lines...); the portal spell is useful, but it gets to the point where your entire game experience is just managing portals to ensure the various dwarves don't take too long to get back home.Final issue: the tech tree is full of connections that map back onto each other, meaning you have to become skilled in all manner of furniture and decoration before you can advance from, say, iron to silver weapons or armour. Seems a bit absurd. While happiness seemed to be a factor in some sense, I never worked it out, so I ended up producing all sorts of spurious tapestries and chairs, and not actually using them, simply because the tech tree demanded it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Craft the World is a fun Minecraft/Terraia style game, held back by an extremely long and boring technology tree and a severe lack of enemies.Unlike most crafting games, progressing from one tier of items to the next does not just require building the correct crafting table and gather enough resources, it also requires you to have advanced the tree by building tons of items at the prior level.Want to build iron swords? Oops, gotta build 5 more wooden sheilds first.Trying to bake a cake for your hungry dwarves? Well, I hope you caught a bunch of fish first, to advance up,Found a vein of platinum you want to craft? Sorry, your dwarves need to master bed & lightbulb construction before they'll even try to make a new set of armor.Combat content (enemy types) run out far too quickly as well.After surviving the nightly zombie raids, and killing the local goblin camp (with your level 1 wooden swords), there's nothing left to fight except god-tier golems in hidden chambers deep underground.  And if you want to fight them? Well, prepare to spend hours mining out every level of the  In the end, Craft the World is a very accurate title. By the end of the game, you'll have mined the entire world, and converted it into a procession of increasingly meaningless cosmetic items, on a quest to advance the technology tree far enough to get some decent combat equipment for your dwarves.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This game is right up my alley.  It's a blend of Terraria with the autonomous command-driven functionality of dwarf fortress.  It's an interesting amalgam of the two games, though not nearly in-depth and strategic as DF, and lacking the insane quantity of content of Terraria.  If the developer maintains a level of involvement half that of the Terraria dev, this game has huge potential.  As it stands right now, early game discovery is a superb experience.  Mid-game, you focus on building yourself up and reaching higher tech levels.  I haven't made it to end-game content yet, but I hear it's lacking.Bottom line, do I recommend it?  Hellz yeah.  And $10 is an excellent price point for this game.  In hindsight I would have purchased it at full price, but I had no idea it would be this good.

												I'm totally new to the concept of crafting games and 12 hrs in, I'm loving it. The tutorial (missing in other things I've tried and given up on) was just right to get me going on how the concept works. I can feel myself getting better and better at crafting the right tools and arming my little guys ready for the onslaught  (love the countdown to the hoard of nasties). Sometimes my little guys ddon't go the way I want and manual control is a bit tedious - but to be able to control my whole game just with a single point and click device means I can keep 3 limbs under a winter blanket and play whilst snuggled up. Nothing negative to say about it really - can't wait to see what the future updates bring.

												This game is just simple fun.  It feels like terraria and lemmings had a baby.  There are definetly some areas that need improvement. I highly recommend this to anyone that likes this style of game in spite of some of the shortcommings.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game has a solid foundation, but has several major design flaws. Since the game already has a lot of positive reviews, I'll focus on why mine is negative.First off, it's extremely slow paced. It requires a lot of micro management, so you can't just set orders and go do something else. But it moves so slowly that you'll be sitting doing nothing for a minute or two after assigning new orders. Set some blocks to mine, trees to cut down, animals to hunt, then open portals near those places. Now wait 2 minutes while your dwarves finish those tasks. Then repeat. In order to play at an engaging speed, I actually used an external program to run the game at triple speed, which improved the game significantly.Second is the crafting "tree". All items, weapons, equipment, decoration, supplies, etc are bunched into groups of 4-5 items. In order to unlock a new group of items, you have to craft a certain number of items from the group (or two) that lead up to it. Crafting a lot of only one item from that group has diminishing returns, so it is best to craft 2-3 of each item in the group. The problem is, it isn't laid out in a tree. The next tier of armor might have furniture and glassware as prerequisites (as an example, I don't remember exactly). But each of THOSE requires 1-2 other groups first. So you can't rush to the items you want: you have to make EVERY ITEM IN THE GAME a few times to progress. This just compounds the first problem, slowing down the game. Even though you could easily just dig down and get mithril to make the best gear in the game, you can't actually craft those items until you've made every single other item in the game several times over. Imagine if in Minecraft, even though you can easily dig down and find diamonds in 10 minutes, you couldn't actually make diamond gear until you've spent 10 hours gathering materials and crafting every other in the game 20 times. Or if in Civilazation, there were no tech trees and you just had to research every single technology, in the same order, every game. That's what it feels like. There's no choice. It gets boring and tedious after the first time. Third is the lack of real progression from level to level in the campaign. There are four "worlds" in the campaign. Beat one, go to the next one. Here's the problem: each world only has a few new items to make. You play world one, get your dwarves decked out in the best gold and mithril gear, and then move on to world two... and you're back collecting sticks and leaves. World two lets you build four "ice" versions of other items, which are only better in that using ice doesn't waste the more valuable resources. Then you go through the whole crafting tree, taking forever to get enough resources to get up to gold and mithril again, so you can go on to world three and start all over again. World four finally adds some new weapons, which is nice, but they aren't a huge improvement on the same weapons you've been using since world one. It just doesn't feel like you're progressing. Normally in a campaign, when you move on to the next world you get access to stronger gear and the like. But in Craft the World, you work through the exact same progression over and over.My overall conclusion is that the game has potential but is poorly designed. A major overhaul could make it really good. Increasing dwarf movement speed so you don't have to micromanage portals for transportation would be amazing. Sorting the tech tree by item type would be a big help. Iron armor -> silver armor -> gold armor, instead of iron armor -> glassware -> fabric dying -> whatever -> silver armor or whatever the progression is. This would let you focus on what you want/need at the moment, instead of wasting your time making items you don't need first. When I need better armor so my dwarves can survive the next invasion, I don't want to have to make a ton of armoires first. The last major change would be changes to the scope of the campaign worlds. World one should be shorter, with iron as the only available metal, and weaker guardians that only require that iron gear to beat. Then world two is slightly larger, with silver added and guardians that require silver to beat. This way, the player actually feels a sense of progression from world to world. As is, it's just painful and quite frankly STUPID to go from mithril right back to wood, and then have to work back up to mithril. Also, don't make me unlock all the crap again in world two, three, four. It's a 100-200 hour game, with only 10-20 hours worth of content.Of course, for a lot of people it isn't just a game where you rush to beat the campaign. Like Minecraft, it's about building your vision of the perfect home. But in Minecraft, when you have a new vision you start a new world and can quickly have everything you need to start building again, but in Craft the World the tech system means that if you start a new world, it'll be at least 10 hours before you start to see your vision take shape.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												If you enjoyed Terraria then Craft the World is the next best thing. The game features a campaign mode with 4 maps which increase in size and difficulty. The objective is to gather materials to create a shelter and equipment to allow your dwarfs to meet increasingly difficult waves of enemies who attack at night. You create everything from armour, weapons, furniture, food and potions with the ultimate goal of opening a portal to the next level. The game worlds are not as large as Terraria and the limited metals make it impossible to fully equip your dwarves in the best armour and equipment except on the larger maps. Unlike Terraria you don’t directly control a single character but instead issue commands which the dwarves then carry out, this allows you to queue large construction projects or mine huge areas and simply sit back and watch the dwarves complete the tasks. You can construct various defences which allow you to automate your defence, I found this part of the game the most enjoyable as your hard mining and crafting is eventually awarded with a base your enemies can’t breech. On the negative side the game suffers from strange path finding issues, sometimes dwarves stand motionless with an icon above their head indicating that they can’t find a way to get to a location. It’s understandable when the location is miles away but as you mine and create complex tunnel systems they become more frequently lost even when going a short distance. It’s also a shame that nothing carries over to the next level. You open a portal to the next map but you start that map with nothing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I'm going to review this game with the premise that it one of a few games that could be categorized as Dwarf Fortress like, and will refer to DF throughout the review. The game has some major flaws, but overall it's a great game and is well worth the price. I'll start with the negatives. The AI is not great. The dwarves have a strange way of prioritizing what needs done, so you can't queue up too many task at once, or it will take forever for the important ones to get finished. They also path terribly sometimes, ignoring nearby warp portals if was built after they decided to go somewhere. They will also walk into a hole another dwarf is about to fill to pick up dirt, and will just stand there deciding what to do next, rather than realize they will be trapped. Also wood is far too important for building for not being able to reliable plant it yourself. You end up using the portal spell to send your dwarves out onto the fringe of the world for a few trees all the time. The tech tree is also very poorly implemented. The order in which the dwarves research things is very strange, with seemingly easy things towards the end of the tree and hard things at the beginning. It also forces you to make countless items you'll never use, simply to advance the tree. Combat can also seem kinda clunky, as dwarves will sometimes waltz away from a monster wave simply because none of the monsters are marked for combat. The lack of a profession system is also very irritating. In DF and many DF like games, you assign your dwarves/gnomes/goblins/etc a job, and they perform that job. Such as smith, miner, logger, etc. In this game all dwarves do everything. There is a skill system (dwarves gain up to 3 skills in things such as logging, swimming, archery, etc), and I've read that a job is done by the dwarf with the highest skill in that task, who is currently not doing anything. While I'm not sure if this system even works, it is a bad idea to begin with. The game can also begin to be repetitive. At 21.6 hours I've beat the first world and have moved onto the second world. You simply begin back at square one, with one dwarf and an empty tech tree. The only difference is that the world is harder. I can easily see how other people with more hours and who have gotten to further worlds say that by world 5 the game is boring. Now to the good. The side view 2D is an interesting perspective, and fresh from many of the other top down view DF like games, or any city builders in general. The fortress defense mechanic is very fun. Although the nightly skeleton/zombie hordes do not get any more challenging, the hourly monster raids do start to get harder. This is until all your dwarves are equipped with mithril weapons/armor, at which point the game becomes fairly easy again. The tech tree, while overall being badly implemented, can do a good job at driving you forward to research new items. There are several types of metal to work with, which leads to a nice flow of upgrading your weapons. There are also several types of walls/roofs (once you finally research them), so you can make cool looking forts. Although the game does discourage making individual bedrooms (by keeping interior doors until well into the tech tree) and this does detract from making interesting looking forts. Once you also get farming (well into the tech tree, this is another negative) you can make interesting looking fortresses with attached underground farms. This is always one of my most fun parts of DF like games. The spells are nice too, and make you feel much more involved than many DF like games. Dwarves getting tired of eating certain food too often, forcing you to take advantage of the different types of food available. While I love Gnomoria, I hate knowing I can just grow wheat and my gnomes will never get tired of eating wheat bread and drinking wheat beer (in fact spamming wheat in it is to your advantage). Overall, the thrill of the first 15-30 hours is great. You want to explore just one more tunnel before you go to sleep, and the portal spell makes exploring the fringes of the world much more accessible. If you don't mind spending 20 dollars on a great 30 hours, and then (from what I've heard) an "eh" another 20 hours before the game is just too repetitive, then this is a great game for you. If you are a fan of a DF and are looking for something less intense and requires less time and energy, this game is also great for you (or if you are too scared to jump straight into DF but want to play a fortress builder).

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												I started playing craft the world just recently and have enjoyed most of the time spent on it, there are a few bugs and interface improvements to make but for the most part its a good game worth it's price.It looks very good and remind me of a few other games like dungeon keeper, minecraft and games like dwarf fortress and there is a risk that you will postpone bedtime to spend only one more hour to complete your latest mastermind design. There is more then meets the eye here and planning your shelter and redesign it as you progress is both fun and rewarding. I only played custom games so far and even if the endgame tend to drag out a bit on large maps I didn't feel like it was to bad and never lacked resources for long. (Lucky perhaps?)What could be improved is the AI that can from time to time drive you nuts when the dwarfs do one stupid thing after another, there could be improvements to be made with tooltips and make it more obvious what armor stats your dwarfs have when you equip better gear. Other thing is that the tech tree could be tuned a bit to make it a bit more interesting and some techs should be moved to a earlier spot in the tech tree to match your progress as you need to expand and go further away from the shelter (elevator, secondary storages and railtracks for example) . I would also love to see some more options for defending your shelter, like more turrets, burning oil, perhaps a drawbridge. If you are into sandbox games and enjoy perfecting your castle and exploring the landscape around it you should be quite happy with this game, it got much to offer even though there are room for improvements.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												After putting in 85 hours of this I should probably write a review...Craft The World is this little hidden gem of a game, combining the lighter sides of both Dwarf Fortress and Terraria in a well polished, enjoyable game. It's one of the few games this year where I've found myself coming back to the game time and time again to indulge in a day of play. Currently it seems to be updated pretty regularly, and the new addition of being able to start rudimentary animal husbandry was a really nice, needed touch. The aesthetic of the game is wonderful - the graphics are just really pleasing to look and the game just oozes it's own unique charm. In all my time of play I've not noticed huge bugs at all, certainly nothing game breaking. There's a really nice touch in that your games are saved on Steam's cloud, so I can load it up elsewhere and just play the same worlds I was on. There are a few cons - the comment that it doesn't have high replayability is a fair one, as once you've beaten a world you've no reason other than pure enjoyment to play the same type of world again. Once you've run out of tech tree there's not so much left to do and mythril will run out eventually. There's no real incentive to build your base beyond straightforward utility - comfort is not so hard to max out provided your walls are of a decent material and it's also far easier to build down instead of up (In fairness though, they are dwarves...). If you have some items they can't pick up, they'll spam broken pathway thoughts all day but give you no clue as to where they are. Finally, and most annoyingly, you will have to craft several of the same item over and over again to get the tech tree to progress. This leads to a bit of a block in the middle section that you'll just have to persevere through.But really, these are just gripes and most of my wants in this game would be wishlists as opposed to game changes. I'd love to see an expansion of the world types - perhaps a fire-type world or a rainforest. I'd also love to see the class roles solidified and with the ability to task those dwarves. For example; disable everyone who isn't a hunter from hunting animals; make it so that only cooks and smiths and carpenters can carry out those tasks. Maybe get some unique 'appearance sets' so everyone doesn't look like a mythril statue in end game?To summarize, if 2D building and defending is your poison, you really can't go wrong with this game. It's well polished, enjoyable, and has its own unique charm. Glad I stumbled across it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Worth every penny. (Or Cent, or whatever currency you think in...)Synopsis: An addictive game where you direct your dwarves to excavate, (For resources), chop, mine, dig, plant, build structures and craft items to complete given levels.There are some magic abilities, like portals which come in handy for speeding up travel, a fiery fireball to roast enemies, and even summon imps to carry goods, freeing up the dwarves for more intensive labor.But this is not just about magic, it i about dwarves, which are known for engineering feats of note, so you can build a railway, allowing your dwarfs to speed from one end of the map to the other, lifts, that essentially do the same, just in a vertical direction.Your dwarves are also skilled in different fighting and crafting skills, like archers, sword wielders, mages and those swinging big meat tenderisers. Crafting skills range from fishing, milling, tree felling, to even simpler forms like swimming and mountain climbing.You need to equip your dwarves with the right tools, and so you craft things like axes, pickaxes, weapons, armour and t tools like backpacks.I've had endless fun, and plenty frustration with this game. At the tim of this writing, I am hinting for the last 6 achievements.This game has elements of Terraria in it, and is a bit of a world builder, as it allows you to craft elaborate homes for the dwarves.The combat is awesome,  but at times frustrating, as they keep attacking when I am busy exploring and excavating for resources.The tech tree does not make sense sometimes, however, I think there is only one point where it becomes a real pain to complete, which is the second last tier, for crafting potions. Having crafted the potions though, helps immensely in the coming final guardian battles.The last improvements made, look great, even though I haven't tried them yet.I disagree with some of the game design elements, however, these "problems" i perceive, do not distract from an awesome gaming experience, with plenty of fun.I am a great supporter of management games, where you direct, and the minions follow, and this game falls squarely into that bracket.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Craft the World is a nice mix of Tower Defence, Base Building and Resource Gathering / Management and after 200 hours of play I can safely say that I have gotten great value for money with this game!You are constantly moving forward one way or another. With a vast tech tree to work through, there is always something new to craft, new weapons, new tools and new decorations are plentiful. Ever increasing waves of an enemy horde will keep you on your toes, complete with a countdown so you know how long you have left to bolster defences and get ready for the pending invasion. Also the main aim of the game is to build a portal and move on to the next new land, for this you must find and defeat the boss creatures hidden in the depth of the world, be careful when digging deep though and more than 1 surprise awaits in the far depths.You are never left bored, not only are you mining to find the Portal (and to gather resources) while waiting for the invading horde but enemies will spawn in unlit areas and the day/night cycle will bring a small horde of enemies to your door each night.There are plenty of tools, weapons and armours for your dwarves to choose from ranging from stone and wooden stuff to mythril, do you go for style over functionality? will your dwarves be melee warriors, archers or mages? finding a balance that suits you can mean the difference between success and failure when attacking strong enemies.Building a home for your dwarves is also important, keep them happy by giving them good food (and maybe a nice little something to drink ;) )and a nice place to live, there are loads of choices in this department, from various walls and floors to fish bowls and comfy chairs. So much to choose from keeps the game fresh.This is a game I always go back to and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes tower defence or resource management games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												After playing other attempts at turning the Dwarf Fortress formula into an easily swallowable pill like Gnomoria and Towns, I feel that this is the first that succeeds all-around. It's a game with simple interface, but still plenty of depth. Dwarves behave in a relatively intelligent manner without you having to micro-manage priorities or wondering why that one task you assigned just isn't getting done, you say it, they do it. And even if there is something you want done straight away, you can always take control of a dwarf directly and do it yourself, or set down a portal to get them closer to what you want them to do. In the campaign, unlockable tech-trees and finding pieces to the portal to the next world give you goals to shoot for, and even after that, there's always something more to improve upon when building your current world.-Notes on Difficulty:- As you play you will be beset by waves of enemies periodically to test your defenses, at first I felt a little worried, but unless you are in permadeath mode, your game won't end even if your very last dwarf dies. Worst case scenario, you lose all your dwarves and the skills they built up, but they will quickly be replaced and they can wear all your previous dwarves equipment. You can quickly repair any destroyed blocks from the previous attack and prepare better for the next one.I highly recommend this for anyone who enjoys Dwarf Fortress, or is even simply interested in it but feels a little overwhelmed. I am hoping for more objects/biomes/creatures in the future!UPDATE: Occasional slowdown if you have too many tasks queued or too many objects on the map, enemy and dwarf pathing isn't perfect, but you can build around it to accommodate them.TIP: You can use F1 to F3 to alter game speed. Important!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								(Edit from an earlier, favorable review after spending more time with the game.)This is a *fantastic* concept that (so far) lacks in execution. The Dwarf Fortress meets tower defense idea is great, but both elements are far too stripped down to be interesting. Crafting and mining is interesting for the early game, but once you've teched to iron the whole thing starts to run on very repetitive rails. You build iron weapons, dig further down, tech to silver, rebuild your weapons with silver, repeat. The tower defense idea has the same problem. A sandbox TD sounds great, but there are only two towers both of which are relatively weak. It also doesn't really matter because by mid game my dwarves could handle most monsters relatively easily anyway.On every level I have fun setting up my initial base, start to get bored by the early mid-game, and by mid to late game am just grinding. There's a lot of potential here, but a lack of variety and challenge keep it from being really interesting. Fortunately this is also all content based. The mechanics and game that they're set up IS really good. Flesh it out more and they'll have a winner on their hands!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Actually very fun. While it may seem similar to Terraria, the game plays differently and has a different aesthetic that reminds this author much more of Dungeon Keeper crossed with Dwarf Fortress. This game is entertaining and engaging despite the field of "Dwarf-likes" being flooded currently. Despite some very odd design decisions and a 2d space, the game stays novel by reducing some of the complex factors of Dwarf Fortress (goblin invasions etc) to a point where they become somewhat stale after a bit. Despite that, the game stays fun by introducing some new surprises in the depths and simplifying gameplay mechanics within a 2d space.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been enjoying this game along with my younger brother and sister. A very addictive and relaxing game as well as just cute and fun. I'll put my pros and cons here to sum up some of the best and worst aspects as of now.Pros: Fun detailed 2D graphics style         Easy to understand crafting interface.         Lots of variety in creatures as well as materials.         A leveling system which grants more and more Dwarves as you go.         A sense of accomplishment as you dig further down and build higher up.         Dwarves have a class assigned to them when they spawn in.Cons: Some pathfinding issues but they are getting better.          Dwarves don't build or dig in the order you give them - As if they had a mind of their own          The music is nice but lacking in variety.          And my main problem with this game, while not a game ruiner by any means, is the translation problems. All in all I will give this game a 9/10 because the pros heavily outweigh the cons and the team working on this has obviously put a lot of love into this gem.Hope this helps someone decide whether or not to buy the game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overall a fun game with a charming art style as well as an interesting dynamic to tech progression that is both probably the game's biggest strength, as well as most glaring weakness. The tech tree is vast and full of neat things to craft and place around or give to your dwarves, but around the halfway point tech progression can slow to a crawl as you scrounge up materials for your seventh soup ladle or umpteenth stone pillar that you won't ever use while desperately trying to claw your way to better weapons and armour so that poor Hunck the blacksmith doesn't get maimed by a beholder for the third time today.This mechanic, while it can be slow-going and grindy at points, does however ensure there's never a lack of things to do while you wait for your bearded minions to finish the latest addon to your fortress or figure out the best manner in which to club a snail to death.The generally casual pace makes this game an excellent time-waster for when you've got nothing to do and a long time to do it while the regular invasions that occur every 40 minutes or so keep things interesting and keep you on your toes and devising clever methods to keep enemies out of your fort and your dwarves' heads firmly on their shoulders.If invasions and tech trees aren't your thing, the game also boasts a sandbox mode, though I personally haven't taken the time to play much with it.Updates and hot fixes are small and frequent, with constant effort being put into improving AI, visual assets, and the overall gameplay experience.Also ghosts are pretty much jerks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am having lots of fun with this game. Graphics are adorable. The game itself has crashed on me a few times but for the most part stable on Mavericks. I'm not always sure what to do which is why I popped out of the game, in order to join forums or google for help. I just started today so a more detailed review coming soon. For now all i have to say is this game definitely lives up to its namesake.Edit: I played this game for some 20 hours straight and got to level 11. This is definitely an addictive game! . Lots of fun. I would say my issues with it being that there are some objects and i have no idea what true benefit they are to my game. The crafting interface although nice is still a bit clunky. You can easily lose your place.  I also had a few building problems at times (places i needed to patch up and other elves just wouldn't get out of the way so they got trapped in walls).. But I expect this would be fixed in later version. It is alpha after all and a very playable one at that. Love the tech tree.. I find it is very well planned out. I'm on first map, but having issues with the very limited resource coal which is required in almost every recipe for a while until you learn how to make coal (makes sense). I would love to see more mouse over information especially on paper doll view of each elf/gnome and his gear. I want to see female gnomes too!Crafting can be a bit drag/click heavy. I fear I will get carpal tunnel just playing the game.TL;DR: Great game!!!  I'm looking forward to the final version. If you like building a base, crafting, and defending your home against enemies this game is for you. There is still an adventure element with exploring other areas for resources too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												This is hands down one of the best games I've played in years.  Easily in the top dozen of my life with Homeworld, Civilizaiton 1/2, Warlords, C&C, FTL, Sea Battle.  It's all about finding the right balance and creating meaningful progression and this game has done it.  Not perfect of course (is anything?) but pretty damn close.Pros- Pretty deep game with the four worlds with lots of hours.- Increased options and strategies with the DLC- Really nice balance between strategic choices and RTS fun- Okay replayability with the four core maps plus creating custom games- No big bugs, very stable game and small bugs are only slightly annoying and easily overcome- Appears to be a developer who listens and cares about the community they've built - I have lots of hope for more DLC and an eventual sequelCons- multiplayer is a little awkward as its inserted into single player games- Dwarves are a little flat from an RPG perspective - three skills per dwarf.  I'd like to see personalities like grumpy dwarf, sleepy dwarf as a simple way to create a stronger conneciton with them.- Some simple techniques can eliminate most of the risk from invading monsters.  Needs a bit more balance here.- More rare/unique items dropped by big monsters would be cool, more tower options would create more defence optionsAmazing game and worth the full price (and even better on sale).   I'd recommend getting the DLC with the game as it's nice to start the game with the additional options created by the DLC.Happy gaming.

content:

Early Access Review
								There are a lot of comments saying this game takes too long or it's only fun for the first few hours but don't quite explain why.Firstly, basic stuff like mining is O.K and I could accept the stone picks being slow but after a while of having to stock up ALL the dwarves with high end picks got expensive, pointless and took to long just so that if some dumb dwarf decided to stop crafting my turrets (Which I'll talk about later :L) would go mining. Secondly after that building is hard as they take ages getting there and can't reach very far, on top of that the que system is buggy meaning you have to CONSTANTLY watch what they are doing.This game might seem like you can make awesome structures with cool bases but truthfully the first base you build will be make of wood, regardless of how good you are as to heal they need a house and nobody has the time to spare taking the old one appart, also if you spawn in a bad place THATS IT you cant move your stock pile!did you finally build that huge base you spent ages on?Well too bad cause the enemy will spawn inside that and kick your♥♥♥♥♥ The crafting system, total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to get to the good stuff you need to craft 15 gargoyles and trust me they are time consuming to both craft and collect the stonethe world looks nice to start but when the "Snap Vines" or whatever they are called start to spread they dont stop, and their hideous.you'll never build a huge army of Dwarves because they are always dying by drowning/falling in lava because of bugs/running into battle armed with clubs instead of letting the armed dwarves fight/general stupidity/not going to bed/trapping themselves in blocksIn summary regardless of how good you think this game will be its not that good, I was SUPER hyped by this but I feel it has taken my money and given me a buggy unfinished game with the *Occasional* updates that add in a few useless things that cause yet more bugsNot worth the money

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Easily the best early access game I have played, and one of only two (the other being 7 days to die) that were actually worth paying for. This game is great. It's kind of like a 2D version of Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria. Although the scope of this game isn't as large as those two, the game has what it needs to stand on its own. The graphics are crisp, the gameplay is solid, and there is a good bit of variety in the (currently 4) world types. I give this game my absolute highest recommendation, and I hope its developers make a fortune on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I played this game, enjoyed it, and recommend it. However it's not the best game in this genre. Which is unfortunate because this game has so much going for it. My biggest gripe is with the enemy raids. There are two types. The nightly attacks are too common and trivial to defend against. I even found myself ignoring them in favour of mining for ore underground. And the second hourly one starts weak but soon escalates in difficulty until I had to hide underground. And then there's the mining. The worlds are too small and resources too scarce. The AI is alright after you understand it but the crafting menu needs some work. Ironic considering the name.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												At first I was a bit skeptical about visual and the game itself, but I do suggest you to give it a try and you won't regret it...You can make orders and let your dwarfs roam an their own, like in DF or assume direct control of one of them and do all the heavy work by yourself, like in terraria. There is plenty of stuff in this game, not actually a lot like in DF or Terraria, but still, plenty. Go fishing... Go hunting... Make yourself a little and cozy farm with animals and wheat. Defend your place with traps, smart design or brute dwarf force, the choise is yours. There is a campaign in this game, but it's a sandbox kind of campaign with a final goal and stuff, I'd suggest to start it to learn the basics of this game... It is a fun time-killer.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am absolutely addicted. I'm almost certain that work will suck tomorrow because I'll be chasing after 'just 1 more mineral' until 3am and I need to be up early. When you consider this is literally just the beginning, you know you're onto a complete winner. Take control of a small 'community' of dwarves, and craft, mine and fight your way to kitting them out with the best armour and putting them in the best home. I thought it would be another Minecraft clone, but this goes much deeper than that. As the game description mentions, it has a Dungeon-Keeper-esque feel, mixed with the crafting of Minecraft and the side scrolling of Terraria.Basically, just buy this game and support these awesome developers. Already dead excited for the finished product!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even though this is still early access, it's an awesome game. The graphics are amazing, and controlling your Dwarf army is hilariously fun. But the game does have it's flaws. My biggest issue is with the Dwarves AI, at one point I sat there and watched as my Dwarf tried to kill a Sheep for 10 MINUTES, and he had a Steel Club, so it should have been easy. Another example is that the Dwarves can have 3 specialties each, which sounds cool, but it's practically useless. If I have a Dwarf who had 20 points in Fishing, he should be the one who goes to fish, but instead it automatically sends a Dwarf with ZERO points in fishing to go fish. Another irritating thing is that when you're telling them to mine a bunch of stuff at a time, they will keep stopping to bring the stuff back to base, I would prefer an OPTION for whether or not they bring the stuff back right away, or just keep mining away, that or have the ones that are already mining, keep mining while the other ones gather the stuff. This gave has the potential to be at least a 9/10, and right now I would give it a 7/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is in the vein of gnomoria. You order your dwarves around to mine and build things. There are some logistics to it since some resources are more limited than others. On the plus side, things can be deconstructed as well so you can regain some of those resources when you need something better in the next tier of the technology tree. You have to fend off waves of baddies, so that keeps it interesting as well. It's a well done builder that, even though it's early access, feels more like a complete game. The dwarves usually work on what you want them to, but they've got a mind of their own as well. I've seen some negative comments that relate to this, but wrangling your people is always an issue when you play games that are god sim-esque. If you're a fan of that sort of gameplay, you already know what you're getting into. There are occasional wonks when the game is sketching out the boundaries of your house, but the devs are active and are making improvements.I highly recommend the game. It's one that you sit down at to play for ten minutes and find yourself still playing after an hour.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
Early Access Review
								All in all, this is a very very good game considering it is still curently only in early access! I havent yet encountered any bugs to my surprise and this game certainly has a lot of potential to be expanded upon, not that there isnt already plenty there for the time being!The only VERY minor problem I have with this game is the difficulty, in that as you progress through the game, it doesn't seem to get much harder as you develop, to the point where even on a game with the difficulty set to nightmare, I am having very little trouble with monsters including the large waves that appear every so often once you reach roughly about the 2 hour mark. The other thing I feel that woild make a good improvement would be the ability to switch at somepoint from a standard game to a permant death game, and then be unable to reverse, as following my above comment, it is quite easy to have a dwarf die in the early stages of the game, but once you reach the stage where you have a base up and running with multiple dwarves, the game does become easier, and I think this may reintroduce some of the challange back into the game at a later stage.However as I said these are very minor points, and all in all a very fun game that has plenty of content and is really promising. I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												In summary, a mining game with dwarves controlled by an AI that could be much better.I did play this game for quite a long time and it does have some replay value but the AI definitely needs updating.I played the first campaign level for 10 or so hours.  Since it takes a while to level up in the tech tree, I've just found that I've been losing dwarves left, right and centre trying to fend off monsters every 45 minutes and attempting to craft stuff at a slow pace.Good change of pace compared to other mining games around.PROS: Different to other mining games where you control a multitude of dwarves (one for every level)You can assign tasks to other dwarves and only control one at a timeSpecialisation of dwarvesCustom game is open ended, easier difficulties do not have annoying portalsZoom out function lets you see obstacles (eg larvae) close to where you have mined on the mapPortal of monsters adds difficulty to the campaign levelsRecipe drops in custom mode are random - you could unlock something that requires a precrafted itemCONS:Dwarves AI is flawed, they fall often and stand around even when they are two squares away from dropped items to pick upTech tree is slow in campaign mode, if it's not unlocked yet, you can't craft it until the recipe is unlocked in the treeIf you don't know what the recipe is in custom mode, you have to wait to unlock the recipe which could happen further in the gameDwarves get hungry too often, they can idle and then get hungry.Normal speed and 2x speed is incredibly slow

												When i first saw the game on steam i thought it was another terraria clone and i marked it as "im not interested". However i watched some videos from one of the lets play youtube users i am following and bhought the game immedeately.This game is a mix of terraria type 2d crafting games and dwarf fortress. You give orders to be done and ai does it for you. You even can control your minions directly if you like. That game has damn one of the greatest pathfinding algorithms i have ever seen. Runs very smooth with very nice graphics. Minions are very cute too.It gives  greate feeling of explore. Very smart new game dynamics that none of such kinds games have. you can achieve some victory on fair numbers of tech tree which many games doesn't have.Developer/developers did a greate job to create such game with really "new" tings we didn't ever seen before. Very smart and neat. Still tings to be done to improove gaming experiance. However game is alot fun to play even withouth the improvements it may need.In my opinion this game deserves its price for giving me lots of fun hours.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Although this game becomes somewhat repetative after a while, it is a fascinating mix of terraria meets gnomeria that is incredibly fun to play. If you enjoy either of those genres then you owe it to yourself to check this game out. The developers are still adding content to this game, so there is always something to do, however I wish there was more variety in the maps. For instance, when you start a new map you can choose either desert, Ice, jungle, and I think normal biomes. It would be nice to see a combination of those mixed in with the procedurally generated terrain so that you can experience that variety within every game and not just across them. All that said, it is a very good game.

Early Access Review
								There are a lot of comments saying this game takes too long or it's only fun for the first few hours but don't quite explain why.Firstly, basic stuff like mining is O.K and I could accept the stone picks being slow but after a while of having to stock up ALL the dwarves with high end picks got expensive, pointless and took to long just so that if some dumb dwarf decided to stop crafting my turrets (Which I'll talk about later :L) would go mining. Secondly after that building is hard as they take ages getting there and can't reach very far, on top of that the que system is buggy meaning you have to CONSTANTLY watch what they are doing.This game might seem like you can make awesome structures with cool bases but truthfully the first base you build will be make of wood, regardless of how good you are as to heal they need a house and nobody has the time to spare taking the old one appart, also if you spawn in a bad place THATS IT you cant move your stock pile!did you finally build that huge base you spent ages on?Well too bad cause the enemy will spawn inside that and kick your♥♥♥♥♥ The crafting system, total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to get to the good stuff you need to craft 15 gargoyles and trust me they are time consuming to both craft and collect the stonethe world looks nice to start but when the "Snap Vines" or whatever they are called start to spread they dont stop, and their hideous.you'll never build a huge army of Dwarves because they are always dying by drowning/falling in lava because of bugs/running into battle armed with clubs instead of letting the armed dwarves fight/general stupidity/not going to bed/trapping themselves in blocksIn summary regardless of how good you think this game will be its not that good, I was SUPER hyped by this but I feel it has taken my money and given me a buggy unfinished game with the *Occasional* updates that add in a few useless things that cause yet more bugsNot worth the money

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game felt very polished compared to so many other games in 'Early Access'. I am very much looking forward to whatever else they plan on implementing.  The game definitely has that Terreria feel but I very much enjoy the dynamic of controlling multiple dwarfs and being able to mold each of them in to their own specific role.  The game also gives you a similar feel of control to the 'hand of god' games such as Black & White, though when you really need to, you can take direct control of a dwarf.  One other little detail that I appreciated was the fact that the dwarfs can be clumbsy and may fall of planks or off walls and take damage.  This attention to detail made the dwarfs feel much more like a believable character than just one of many bots that will run around and do your bidding with no faulter.I could go on about the features that I enjoy about this game (and at the time of writing this I have only played it for just over 3 hours) but I would highly suggest you play it for yourself.

												I definitely Recommend this game to any fans of building/Sims type games.ProsVery nice graphics for this type of gamegood solid gameplaylots of different things to buildThe dwarfs definitely invent some pretty random funny situations - for example falling face first into a hole full of ant type insects only to be eaten seconds later.nice sound effectsConsonly thing I dont like about this game is a lack of muiltiplayer but then again its advertised as single only, so thats not really an issue, it just annoys me but hey if the developer reads this, add muiltiplayer in the sequel.ok now lets get to the basic description of the gamebasically you start with one dwarf and through completing tasks and stuff you eventually get more and unlock more items to build,while fending off random goblin raids, zombies at night and also Timed raids from beholders and the like.eventually hopefully becoming a dwarf fortress to be proud of.great game I give it a good score of 8 out of 10.for me it loses one point for not having muiltplayer which I think could have been alot of fun.and it loses a second point simply because you gotta give dwarfs something to aim for! if I gave the game 9 the dwarfs would just get lazy!If you dont have this game and you like building and management games, then you should get it

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												The best way to play this game to ignore the campaign (there isn't really one anyway) and jump in to a custom world. I prefer the sandbox mode for tech since this lets you build any item without the tedium of being forced to craft rubbish in order to move up the tree.And then... set your own challange and have fun with it. This game runs great even on my very old laptop so anyone should be able to play it without worrying about your PC specs.It does take a long time to play but I see this as a positive aspect to the game.It is described as having tower defence elements to it - well it doesn't. You can build two towers but they will be destroyed in seconds are currently useless items.Each of the (currently) three worlds present their own challanges and apparently more are coming.If you are a patient player who enjoys spending hours mining and building you base then you will probably have fun with this. More tech, worlds and game customisation could make this a very very good game.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												While most express their distain for Steam's early access, Craft The World is the prime example of possible success to early access. I have owned this game since it's early access days and I've never looked back. The dev's listen to their community, creating updates that we (the players) want to see. The game is beautiful, silly (I love when the dwarfs fall and grumble), and overall enchanting. It's nearly impossible to play this game for only an hour at a time, simply because it's so addicting and you want to "just" get one more level, one more row cleared, craft one more batch of iron picks, or defeat just one more wave of zombies. I hope the developers continue to update this game for a long time, and I can't wait to see their other titles.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												I'm totally new to the concept of crafting games and 12 hrs in, I'm loving it. The tutorial (missing in other things I've tried and given up on) was just right to get me going on how the concept works.  I love how the night brings in monsters to combat - but not so severe as you die on night one! I can feel myself getting better and better at crafting the right tools and arming my little guys ready for the onslaught  (love the countdown to the hoard of nasties). Sometimes my little guys ddon't go the way I want and manual control is a bit tedious - but to be able to control my whole game just with a single point and click device means I can keep 3 limbs under a winter blanket and play whilst snuggled up. As a starter game this has been great and I can see how there is potential to up my skill and get more out of the game as an advancing player. Nothing negative to say about it really - can't wait to see what the future updates bring.
