number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												WOW! I mean seriously! WOW!ImpressionThis game is just simply amazing! I bought it while it was on sale, however, I would gladly have payed full price. The game is currently in early access phase. Sometimes, with early access there is definitely some bugs or some issues with the game. This is true at this point. But the issues are minor enough that I really don’t mind a lot. I’m sure they will iron them out and if they don’t, the game is still amazing and I would still pay full price. What is it?	This game has some definite parallels to popular games such as Terraria. That isn’t a bad thing either. The success of Terraria is undeniable. I have played many hours of that game myself. This is NOT a terraria clone however. This has similar features and gameplay models but it is far from the same. In this game you are more of a dwarf god in that you tell them to chop a tree down and they go to work. You don’t have one character to traverse the world with, you control multiple characters to tell what to do and watch the magic. Still want that control of being a character? Don’t worry, they got you covered. You can individually control the dwarfs as well. There are also a lot of great twists on old enemies as well as some spectacular new ones. Did I mention there is also experience and reward as such? This is great since nothings is worse then the same old dwarf with the same old abilities. You can also outfit your cool warriors with armor, weapons, tools, fishing poles, and so much more. The goal is to survive and thrive into a great dwarf community. I have over 5 hours of play time as of now and that’s what I know so far. I’m absolutely amazed at how good this game is.Buy or Fly?	The ultimate question you’re probably asking yourself is, “Should I buy this damn game or not?” Well, if you like boring straightforward cookie cutter games with absolutely predictable gameplay, then don’t buy this game. If you like fun, new and creative ways to play a mix of genres, then this is a MUST BUY! I would absolutely recommend this game. This game is on iPhone and iPad?! Buy or Fly?	Silly question. YES! I bought it on both Steam and my iPhone/iPad already! It’s the same game on both but a slightly different experience. Either one is worth buying but I say buy both!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												I've put in over 30 hours.  I'm not even crafting mithril weapons and armor yet.  Instead, I'm growing wheat to make beer.  The dwarves love beer and consume lots of it.Oh yeah, there is the monster portal that opens every 45 minutes.  Every time I survive, I tell myself I should go to bed.  Next thing I know, there is 7 minutes left until the next portal opens and I've upgraded armor or weapons and think I should try it out...just one more time.The dwarf AI is not great - however, that's part of the charm.  You have to save these guys.  Build signs to deter them or craft doors (and lock them).  I've enjoyed my time in it.  It's fun.  If you like Terraria and/or crafting games, give it a chance.Update:  I'm now over 175 hours into the game.  It's an obsession.  The tech tree is huge - I've built everything and am on the last part of the campaign.  I've learned to hate the ghosts and gargoyles.  They are annoying.  I more than got my money out of this game.  However, I've learned it's not for everyone.  The game can be tedious at times.  You will also get frustrated with the AI - it can make some really poor choices.  You will also hate the damn ghost - I'd like to just turn them off.  I don't see the point.Wish list if there is ever a "part 2":-Upgradable tower defenses.  Yes, we have the archer tower and tesla-thing.  I would like more.-What about adding golems?  I wouldn't mind having some that could haul materials, patrol, and perhaps even do some mining.  Once you start crafting silver armor - the game shifts and requires you to mine lots of metals.  I have been giving orders that take 30 minutes or so - I do something else while they are mining.  This is tedious and gets boring.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Love the single player! I may have sold my soul if given the opportunity when I first found this game considering how many hours I put into it in a short span of time. It's cute, fun, and is completely engrossing trying to gear your little dwarves for ever bigger, badder things.The beta multiplayer... I'm a tad biased, I'll admit that right away. I play cooperatively with my girlfriend with any game we find that we can play together because we're both so competative that playing against each other is just a bad idea. Neither of us realized that the multiplayer (at least so far) seems to be aimed toward playing competatively. Perhaps we missed an option somewhere where you can change it to coop but obviously we didn't see one. In short, I was unimpressed for that singular reason. I think as an actual competative game, it's probably fine but I wasn't playing for that reason so can't really say. So, aside from the non-coop multiplayer, I give this game 5/5 stars! :DPS~ Girlfriend says she saw and clicked the coop button but it still didn't feel like coop and considering I had no idea and saw no difference in gameplay, I'm inclined to agree.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												This is a really good, really interesting game. I bought it a while ago and I've played it off and on, and watched as the developers have taken this game from a rough concept to a fully-realized gem. It's unlike anything I've ever played, so you might find some parts of it a bit frustrating. You'll be tempted to just walk around and carve stuff up like in any other world-building game, but since you're giving the dwarves directions, you need a lot of patience while they do their thing. So the game becomes this kind of relaxing experience instead. You tell them general things to do and they'll get to work, but at their own pace. At that point you kind of just sit back and watch the magic happen. In that sense, it's sort of a hybrid of terraria and sim city. It's really interesting, and I love checking in every now and then and seeing what they've added to the game lately. The devs are great at listening to feedback and seem to work tirelessly, so I wish them all the best. :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Welcome to Craft the World: a game that has dozens and dozens of reasons to play it, and one painfully glaring reason to never buy it anyway.  It looks good, it runs smooth, it doesn't crash, and it's a charming combination of Motherload and Dwarf Fortress.  If you haven't played those games, think of it as a Minecraft RTS.  If you don't know what that is... I can't help you.  The monsters are cool, the object interactions are neat, the tech-tree is a bit obnoxious but at least it takes you in the right direction without overwhelming you all at once.  That said, I could not recommend this game under any circumstances because the AI is flat broken.  Your dwarves are beyond mentally handicapped.  Orders given are sometimes ignored, or handed off to the dwarf who is farthest from whatever it is that you're trying to do.  Occasionally your dwarves will just wander off or stand stock still and almost nothing you can do will make them budge.   They'll walk off cliffs given the slightest opportunity, if there's a group of enemies they can wander into 1v7 then they'll find it, and they'll only rarely do the jobs suited to the skills they've got.    Trying to get these little hairballs on legs to mount anything resembling an organized defense is utterly hopeless.  Often they'll ignore the first five enemies, run into the middle of them so they can attack that one zombie at the back, and then pretty much die instantly.   The only way to work around the horrible, horrible AI is to exploit the equally horrible AI of the monsters and use terrain to contain them until day break.  Or play on one of the easier modes.  Both options suck, don't do it, don't buy it, turn and run in the other direction.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Craft the World is a marvelous game! Think of Dwarf Fortress meets Terraria. I often found myself screaming at my laptop, swearing at the dwarves, and threatening to take their beer rations away for their stupidity. Building is fun, but once you get halfway through the 1st campaign you really should start it over to do things the right way/easy way from the beginning. It will save you a lot of trouble in the end. THE RATS!!!! I know. They are irritating as all get out! It took me forever to figure out how to permanently get them to leave so I'm going to share that recommendation with you right here........ Raise you comfort level above 60%. I noticed that around 60% I never saw another damn rat again... buuuuut... the downside is that the rats are great for leather.. So.. be aware. I give this game 10/10 and recommend it to everyone.

												10/10 would drown again.What can I say? I've got nearly 700 hours on record for this game.  Clearly I love it.  It is an immensely satisfying builder/crafter with RTS elements.  I find the graphics and gameplay much better and more intuitive than Terraria and other similar games.The only things I would add are:1) A more extensive tutorial, potentially clearer campaign goals or some starter levels for teaching players. I am still discovering shortcut keys that seriously improve gameplay.2) Mod support. Oh, come on, if even I can mod the data files locally to change up the gameplay, this can't be a huge issue.3) Extend the multiplayer. Allow multiplayer games to be stored/hosted so that you can come back to them. I've played quite a lot of coop and those games can last all day.

												My previous review was negative, they added a lackluster DLC that effectivly broke the base game.  Over the course of a few days they've repaired the game so it functions.  Now I'm still not impressed with the DLCs, the fact that multi-player isn't a base feature is a real drawback, but the content in them is somewhat nice to be totally fair.Over all I do enjoy playing the game, its got the Lemmings appeal with some solid crafting fun.  Some people say the hourly attacks are too frequent - they can be frustrating but the additional conent adds enough base defence that it gets pretty easy and without that content there is certainly a hump but its doable.Tl;dr The base game is fun, the DLCs are weak but on sale often and imo worth the sale price.  They also fx bugs which is a credit to the developers.

												Sort of a soft dwarf fortress.Not much micro manement, which is cool, you basically build up guys by adding weaponds, tools and armor.You get skill books too that let you turn them into cooks, and warriors.Pros:Excellent graphics and animation. i am not a fan of Smooth SVG graphics, but thease guys actually put time into doin shadeing and adding lots of small details.Games take a long time to play, so you can sort of experement, and you et to know your dwarf.Cons:Skilltree is a little weird, you have to make all sorts of things before you can even build walls and doors to protect them. I found out that you an use mud as a makeshift material, but your only first option is a top-down hatch which means you are forced to start building underground rather than building up where you can be safe.Once you get wood walls, and side entrance doors the building actually becomes fun, because you can start getting creative.I have been playing for quite a wile now, and found out just recently that there are monsters, and layers of other things far beneath me, so after all this time, i still haeve things to discover.It will force you to make a multiplayer portal, but you can ALT-F4 once someone finally connects, so you can go back to playing solo.Not sure if visiting other biomes is just multiplayer only, or if it actually means other worlds to discover?,,, I am stuck pretty much on the first campaign world.Well anyway, it is a fun little game, that does not take too much effort to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I'm going to review this game with the premise that it one of a few games that could be categorized as Dwarf Fortress like, and will refer to DF throughout the review. The game has some major flaws, but overall it's a great game and is well worth the price. I'll start with the negatives. The AI is not great. The dwarves have a strange way of prioritizing what needs done, so you can't queue up too many task at once, or it will take forever for the important ones to get finished. They also path terribly sometimes, ignoring nearby warp portals if was built after they decided to go somewhere. They will also walk into a hole another dwarf is about to fill to pick up dirt, and will just stand there deciding what to do next, rather than realize they will be trapped. Also wood is far too important for building for not being able to reliable plant it yourself. You end up using the portal spell to send your dwarves out onto the fringe of the world for a few trees all the time. The tech tree is also very poorly implemented. The order in which the dwarves research things is very strange, with seemingly easy things towards the end of the tree and hard things at the beginning. It also forces you to make countless items you'll never use, simply to advance the tree. Combat can also seem kinda clunky, as dwarves will sometimes waltz away from a monster wave simply because none of the monsters are marked for combat. The lack of a profession system is also very irritating. In DF and many DF like games, you assign your dwarves/gnomes/goblins/etc a job, and they perform that job. Such as smith, miner, logger, etc. In this game all dwarves do everything. There is a skill system (dwarves gain up to 3 skills in things such as logging, swimming, archery, etc), and I've read that a job is done by the dwarf with the highest skill in that task, who is currently not doing anything. While I'm not sure if this system even works, it is a bad idea to begin with. The game can also begin to be repetitive. At 21.6 hours I've beat the first world and have moved onto the second world. You simply begin back at square one, with one dwarf and an empty tech tree. The only difference is that the world is harder. I can easily see how other people with more hours and who have gotten to further worlds say that by world 5 the game is boring. Now to the good. The side view 2D is an interesting perspective, and fresh from many of the other top down view DF like games, or any city builders in general. The fortress defense mechanic is very fun. Although the nightly skeleton/zombie hordes do not get any more challenging, the hourly monster raids do start to get harder. This is until all your dwarves are equipped with mithril weapons/armor, at which point the game becomes fairly easy again. The tech tree, while overall being badly implemented, can do a good job at driving you forward to research new items. There are several types of metal to work with, which leads to a nice flow of upgrading your weapons. There are also several types of walls/roofs (once you finally research them), so you can make cool looking forts. Although the game does discourage making individual bedrooms (by keeping interior doors until well into the tech tree) and this does detract from making interesting looking forts. Once you also get farming (well into the tech tree, this is another negative) you can make interesting looking fortresses with attached underground farms. This is always one of my most fun parts of DF like games. The spells are nice too, and make you feel much more involved than many DF like games. Dwarves getting tired of eating certain food too often, forcing you to take advantage of the different types of food available. While I love Gnomoria, I hate knowing I can just grow wheat and my gnomes will never get tired of eating wheat bread and drinking wheat beer (in fact spamming wheat in it is to your advantage). Overall, the thrill of the first 15-30 hours is great. You want to explore just one more tunnel before you go to sleep, and the portal spell makes exploring the fringes of the world much more accessible. If you don't mind spending 20 dollars on a great 30 hours, and then (from what I've heard) an "eh" another 20 hours before the game is just too repetitive, then this is a great game for you. If you are a fan of a DF and are looking for something less intense and requires less time and energy, this game is also great for you (or if you are too scared to jump straight into DF but want to play a fortress builder).
